so I gave a crack at vibe coding a risk neutral pricing model for IRM under some assumptions:
 - no yield bearing collateral
 - stationary marginal distribution of utilisation, u ~ Uniform[0,1] - special case of â€œJacobi diffusionâ€
 - supply rate r_supply(u) = u * r_borrow(u)
 - risk neutral LPs obeying: E[u r_borrow(u) ] - ExpectedLoss = risk_free_rate

I tested this for risk free rate of 4.5% and a linear kink model of `min=3% kink(90%)=10% max=100%` and backed out annualised expected loss (bad debt) and it came to 3.9% annualised of bad debt

I would say yes. When did you see a real fight for L1 dominance recently?
The incumbents are entrenched.

Thereâ€™s an interesting book on this topic called â€œThe Innovators Dilemmaâ€ which shows that disruption generally always fails to materialise when you challenge an incumbent at the same KPI.

BTC didnâ€™t compete with Fiat KPIs of speed, UX or convenience: It competed on defensible scarcity and decentralisation.
SOL & ETH didnâ€™t win on scarcity or decentralisation - they competed created a new KPI of programability

No L1 that tries to do differentiate on following will succeed imo:
 - speed / UX / convenience will disrupt as objectively users rejected those KPIs so you damn yourself to being a testing ground for ETH & SOL
 - scarcity / decentralisation - you will be a shit bitcoin
 - programability - you will be a shit ETH / SOL

The same is true of iPhones - Apple became dominant ever since they combined the iPod with a Nokia3310 the iterative process afterwards isnâ€™t disruption.

The other thought pattern is that privacy is impossible on any venue so we adopt max privacy and afford low value* irregular transactions with anonymity whereas regular flows and large trades will always be effectively public

* even then if you send a good prime number youâ€™re likely to be fingerprinted

In quant trading one of the main ways to trade is to find and identify recurrent patterns from obfuscated flows. Two big examples being 1) end of month / quarter FX rebalancing 2) ETF rebalancing - both attempt to be private using dark pools and other off exchange execution but their market impact [gives a signature and we can trade them easily](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-01-09/nomura-s-mcelligott-sees-max-short-trend-quants-speeding-rally)

In that case if anyone reports any TVL metrics or value exchange privacy is basically very difficult â€¦ the above link shows examples on the most liquid global markets where ETFs & funds have a mandate to trade less that 1% daily volume and we can still pin their flows down
How do you get true privacy on a public blockchain ? Is the only way to make all transactions volumes private including all value transfers ?

It is not sync yet, but going towards it. 

In short, it is a connecting layer between participating chains allowing easy vaultbridge integration (for bridged yields, like katana has), and programmatic bridging that is arguably simpler and more robust than traditional SPOF bridges. 

It unifies the assets being bridged behind a "native" asset, and uses a single entry point on L1 for all the asset balances, such that deeper (unified) liquidity and easier balance keeping becomes possible (no multiple versions of wrapped token per chain). It also has "pessimistic proofs" which basically makes sure no chain can withdraw from this unified bridge more than it put in, so less spillover risk if a chain gets rekt.

I go through it a bit in this old talk: https://youtu.be/u7fJ0oECxQU?si=_LijWPQwY-S_cNP0

1) It's not "sometimes", this is a persistent fee for this route. It's almost always there.

2) There is $30M of ETH in your pool on Berachain and there is $13M of ETH in your pool on mainnet. And 7 day volume is at $8M. 
Where are these liquidity issues supposed to be and which protocol is this "protecting"?

3) Why can there be a liquidity issue at all. We lock our ETH into your contract on mainnet and you mint ETH out of thin air on Berachain. Why is there ever a case where there is not enough ETH for the way back?
It's not that the Berachain ETH is escaping to other L2s as well since it's not a OFT token. 

4) You make it "invisible" for users on the way in that you'll tax them on the way out. This is what crooks do.
lol

Gm - the V2 protocol is pretty complex in how it handles fees so I won't dive to it to explain why it isn't crooksdom lol. Also just to be clear - there's absolutely no re-hypothecation. 

Stargate has an offchain planning module that dynamically updates prices. This only ever goes above "market" rate for one reason. A very very popular pathway that is draining a particular pool on a particular chain will drive up fees so as to protect the protocol from reducing it's liquidity on that chain too quickly. Bera->Ethereum has this happen sometimes because frankly it's quite popular. Simultaneously, the protocol will incentivise the reverse routes (Ethereum-> ** any other chain) so as to improve the liquidity. Sophisticated actors quite quickly spot these opportunities and take the arb.

This is described in our docs, and is well understood by all of our partners who we launch with. We're working on plenty of ways to make this more invisible to the users - so apologies that you had this happen, but it'll become less frequent. Happy Bridging ðŸ™‚
No fees

And when you ask them what determines this "dynamic liquidity dependent" fee and what needs to happen that it drops down to 0 again (where it should be), and point out to them that there is ample liquidity for that route according to their own UI, they tell you the "ai planning module internal mechanics details are not publicly disclosed because this entity is a competitive advantage over other apps, allowing Stargate to be effective in capital management". Effective in capital management? We locked that ETH into your contract on Ethereum when we bridged it to Berachain, so return it ffs. What do you mean "effective in capital management"? That you rehypothecated it by minting the same ETH on mainnet to multiple chains?
